You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: both core and overall pce price inflation were expected to be damped by low rates of resource utilization, falling import prices, and easing cost pressures as a result of the sharp net declines in oil and other raw materials prices since last summer.\n                "}]

Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: votes for this action: messrs. greenspan, mcdonough, ferguson, gramlich, hoenig, jordan, kelley, mcteer, meyer, and mses.\n                "}]

If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. longer-term inflation expectations are little changed.\n                "}]

If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: economic performance in line with their current forecasts would at some point require an adjustment to policy toward a less accommodative stance once more definitive indications of sustained strengthening started to emerge.\n                "}]
2025-05-04 00:20:10,015 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence implies that the Fed expects to tighten monetary policy (less accommodative stance) when the economy shows sustained strengthening, indicating a hawkish stance."
}

If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. 2025-05-04 00:20:16,804 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Federal Reserve System\'s monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the expansion in economic activity was anticipated to lead to a slow reduction in resource slack over the projection period, and the unemployment rate was expected to decline gradually to the staff's estimate of its longer-run natural rate.\n                "}]
2025-05-04 00:20:16,804 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence expects a gradual decline in unemployment rate, indicating a slow reduction in resource slack, which suggests a dovish stance."

When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: forthcoming data on capital spending including new orders and contracts were likely to point to a weaker uptrend in business fixed investment.\n                "}]

"justification": "The sentence indicates a weaker uptrend in business fixed investment, suggesting a slowdown in economic growth, which may require accommodative monetary policy."

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: private nonfarm employment rose at a solid pace in june, as in recent months, while total government employment decreased further.\n                "}]

"justification": "The sentence indicates a solid pace of private nonfarm employment, which suggests a strong labor market, easing inflation concerns and potentially requiring accommodative monetary policy."

If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: more fundamentally, however, the income and wealth effects that were boosting household expenditures generally should help to sustain a perhaps somewhat diminished but still high level of homebuilding activity for a while, despite higher mortgage financing costs.\n                "}]

2025-05-04 00:20:40,497 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Federal Reserve System\'s monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the sharp decline in oil prices weighed on inflation compensation and left a mixed imprint on other asset markets.\n                "}]
2025-05-04 00:20:40,499 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The decline in oil prices is likely to reduce inflationary pressures, which could ease concerns and lead to a more accommodative monetary policy stance."
}

productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: but the dollar depreciated, on net, over the remainder of the intermeeting period, reflecting concerns about an escalation of trade frictions prompted by the u.s. imposition of import quotas on chinese textiles, the ability of the united states to continue to finance its current account deficit, and risks stemming from developments in afghanistan, iraq, and turkey.\n                "}]

"justification": "The sentence mentions dollar depreciation, which is a dovish indicator according to the annotation guide."
