If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in their discussion of the foreign economic outlook, participants generally viewed the risks from the fiscal and financial problems in greece as having diminished somewhat, although it was observed that greece still faced many challenges and that greek economic progress was likely to be limited over the near term.\n                "}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the committee currently does not anticipate selling agency mortgage-backed securities as part of the normalization process, although limited sales might be warranted in the longer run to reduce or eliminate residual holdings.\n                "}]

Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, they judged that purchases of longer-term treasury securities would only modestly improve conditions in private credit markets at present, and that completing already-announced plans to purchase large quantities of agency debt and mortgage-backed securities and to support certain asset-backed securities markets was, in current circumstances, likely to be a more effective way to employ the federal reserve balance sheet to support credit flows to, and spending by, households and businesses.\n                "}]

If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: similarly, employment would be temporarily depressed by the hurricanes, but, abstracting from those effects, employment gains were anticipated to remain solid, and the unemployment rate was expected to decline a bit further by year-end.\n                "}]

increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: staff review of the economic situation the information reviewed at the january 29-30 meeting indicated that the expansion in overall economic activity slowed in the fourth quarter of last year, reflecting weather-related disruptions and other transitory factors, but private domestic final demand grew at a solid rate.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: and the recent firming in oil prices, if sustained, was anticipated to boost domestic energy production.\n                "}]

"justification": "The sentence mentions an increase in oil prices, which is a hawkish indicator as it may lead to higher inflation."

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. 2025-05-04 00:21:29,245 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Federal Reserve System\'s monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: several participants discussed the pickup in residential investment in the first quarter.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence mentions a pickup in residential investment, which is a positive economic indicator, suggesting a dovish stance."

\\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the intermeeting averages of the effective federal funds rate and the secured overnight financing rate remained unchanged from the previous intermeeting period averages, at 9 basis points and 8 basis points, respectively.\n                "}]
2025-05-04 00:21:31,797 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence only reports on the unchanged rates without providing any insight into the Fed's expectations or actions, indicating a neutral stance."

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the civilian unemployment rate fell to 5.7 percent in august despite advances in claims for unemployment insurance.\n                "}]
2025-05-04 00:21:32,749 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The decrease in the civilian unemployment rate suggests a strengthening labor market, which could ease inflation concerns and reduce the need for tighter monetary policy."

Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: consistent with lower mortgage rates, home-purchase mortgage originations increased, reversing a yearlong decline.\n                "}]
2025-05-04 00:21:35,247 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The increase in home-purchase mortgage originations, driven by lower mortgage rates, suggests an expansionary monetary policy, which is dovish."
